facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 113 of 1953 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 113 of 1953. Appeal from the Judgment and Decree, dated the 25th day of March, 1952, of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay

facts.text: Appeal from High Court of Bombay judgment dated March 25, 1952 by Bavdekar and Dixit JJ. in Appeal No. 554 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree, dated the 25th day of March, 1952, of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay  Bavdekar and Dixit JJ.  in Appeal No. 554 of 1951, from Original Decree arising out of the Judgment and Decree, dated the 30th day of June, 1951,

facts.text: Original decree from Court of Joint Civil Judge, Senior Division of Thana, dated June 30, 1951 in Special Suit No. 12 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: from Original Decree arising out of the Judgment and Decree, dated the 30th day of June, 1951, of the Court of the Joint Civil Judge, Senior Division of Thana, in Special Suit No. 12 of 1949.

facts.text: Partition suit between 6 brothers of a joint Hindu family.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal arises out of a partition between 6 brothers of a joint Hindu family. The joint family carried on joint family business of a grocery shop, liquor shops, a ration shop, a motor-bus service and also moneylending under the name of Sontakke Brothers.

facts.text: Joint family businesses: grocery shop, liquor shops, ration shop, motor-bus service, moneylending under Sontakke Brothers.

anchor.surface_text: The joint family carried on joint family business of a grocery shop, liquor shops, a ration shop, a motor-bus service and also moneylending under the name of Sontakke Brothers. The family also Possessed immovable and movable property.

facts.text: Balkrishna Sitaram Sontakke is the eldest brother and plaintiff respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Balkrishna Sitaram Sontakke is the eldest of the brothers and is the plaintiff respondent in the present appeal. He will be referred to hereafter as the plain-tiff.

facts.text: Up to 1944, brothers lived and messed together; income kept with plaintiff. It is common ground.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that up to 1944 the brothers were living and messing together and the income from the family business used to be kept with the plaintiff.

facts.text: From April 14, 1945, parties began to appropriate proceeds of businesses separately.

anchor.surface_text: From April 14, 1945, the situation changed and the parties began to appropriate the proceeds of the various businesses carried on by them separately to themselves.

facts.text: Plaintiff ran liquor shops; defendants 1 and 2 ran motor-bus service; defendant 4 ran grocery shop.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff was running the liquor shops, defendants Nos. I and 2 who are the appellants, were carrying on the motor-bus service business while defendant No. 4 was running the grocery shop.

facts.text: Attempt to partition through arbitrators failed.

anchor.surface_text: The parties tried to have partition effected between them through arbitrators but the attempt failed.

facts.text: On June 29, 1945, five brothers filed suit for partition No. 39 of 1945 against plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: On June 29, 1945, all the five brothers filed a suit for partition against the plaintiff of all joint family properties including the accounts of all the businesses. The suit was numbered 39 of 1945.

facts.text: Suit No. 39 of 1945 compromised on March 7, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: It was companypromised on March 7, 1946.

facts.text: Compromise declared accounts prior to 1942 correctly maintained; arbitrators for 1942 to March 31, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: By this companypromise it was declared that prior to 1942 all the accounts of the various businesses had been companyrectly maintained and shown, that the parties had agreed to have arbitrators appointed through Court for examining the accounts from 1942 up to March 31, 1946,

facts.text: Each brother to get one-sixth share in cash balance as of March 31, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: and for determining the amount due up to that date. Each of the brothers was to get one -sixth share in the cash balance as found on March 31, 1946, upon examination of accounts by the arbitrators.

facts.text: Movable property including stock-in-trade to be divided equally.

anchor.surface_text: All the movable property of the joint family including the stock-in-trade of all the family businesses was to be divided equally among all the brothers.

facts.text: Plaintiff to have one-sixth share in motor garage; defendants 1 and 2 to pay price.

anchor.surface_text: The companypromise further declared that the plaintiff was to have one-sixth share in the motor garage and that defendants 1 and 2 were to pay the price of one-sixth share to him.

facts.text: One brother was minor; court accepted compromise as beneficial, passed preliminary decree July 25, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: One of the brothers was a minor and the Court finding the companypromise to be for the benefit of the minor accepted it and passed a pre- liminary decree in terms of the companypromise on July 25, 1947.

facts.text: Plaintiff filed fresh suit on February 23, 1949 for share of profits and assets of motor business after March 31, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff, however, companymenced a fresh suit on February 23, 1949, companyfining his relief to his share of the profits and assets Of the motor business carried on by defendants Nos. 1 and 2 after March 31,1946.

facts.text: Plaintiff's case: compromise made in hurry, omitted future conduct of motor business; still joint.

anchor.surface_text: His case was that the companypromise was made in a hurry, that the parties omitted to provide in the companypromise about the future companyduct of the motor business from April 1, 1946, that the motor business was still a joint family business

facts.text: Defence: compromise after deliberation; accounts should have been to April 14, 1945 but agreed to March 31, 1946; barred by res judicata.

anchor.surface_text: In defence it was pleaded that the companypromise was made after due deliberation, that accounts of the motor business and grocery shop should actually have been taken up to April 14, 1945, the date of disruption of the joint family status, but the parties agreed by way of companypromise that account of all family businesses should be taken up to March 31, 1946. It was also pleaded that the claim was barred by res judicata.

facts.text: Civil Judge found suit not barred by res judicata, not obtained by fraud, compromise not due to mistake.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the issues framed in the case the Civil Judge found that the suit was number. barred by reason of the decision in the previous suit No. 39 of 1945, that the decision in that suit was number obtained by fraud and misrepresentation and that the companypromise in the previous suit was number due to a mistake or misunderstanding.

facts.text: Civil Judge held motor business post-partition analogous to partnership after dissolution; liable under s.37 Partnership Act; preliminary decree for accounts from 31.3.46 to final decree date.

anchor.surface_text: Despite these findings the Civil Judge held that although the motor business carried on after the partition had ceased to be a joint family business yet as it was carried on by some members of a family their position was analogous to that of a partner carrying on partnership after dissolution and applying the principle underlying section 37 of the Partnership Act he held that the two brothers carrying on the motor business were liable to account.

facts.text: High Court modified decree: accounts to date businesses discontinued, not to final decree; not barred by res judicata or O.II r.2; applied s.90 Trusts Act.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal Bavdekar J. with whom Dixit J. agreed modified the decree of the trial Court by directing that the accounts were to be taken up to the date when the businesses discontinued and number up to the date of the final decree. The learned Judges held that the cause of action for the present suit was different from the cause. of action in the previous suit and that the suit was number barred by res judicata or by Order II, rule 2, of the Code of Civil Procedure.

facts.text: Plaintiff gave notice through pleader on December 12, 1945 to run liquor shops exclusively from April 1, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: He gave a numberice to his brothers through pleader on December 12, 1945, stating inter alia the following - The period of  licence for  the liquor shops at the said places expires by end of March, 1946.

facts.text: Plaintiff had Rs. 13,000 cash in hand; brothers had Rs. 3,000.

anchor.surface_text: Although the plaintiff says that he intended to pay for the auction of liquor shops by borrowing he was really in a position of vantage for he admittedly had Rs. 13,000 cash in hand as against the Rs. 3,000 his brothers had.

facts.text: Plaintiff filed application on November 22, 1947 alleging misapprehension re compromise; abandoned April 6, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: It is also significant that after the companypromise the plaintiff  Balkrishna  filed an application before the Civil Judge in which he alleged that when he agreed in the companypromise that the accounts of the various businesses should be up to the 31st March, 1946, he was under a misapprehension... The application was made on November 22, 1947. His pleader, however, stated on April 6, 1948 The application is abandoned

facts.text: Supreme Court held compromise confined accounts to March 31, 1946; no reopening; plaintiff barred by res judicata and O.II r.3 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that the companypromise closed once for all the companytroversy about taking any account of the joint family businesses including the motor business after the 31st March, 1946, and the plaintiff is bound by the terms of the companypromise and the companysent decree following upon it. The obvious effect of this finding is that the plaintiff is barred by the principle of res judicata
barred by res judicata.

holdings.text: The compromise confines the taking of all accounts of joint family businesses upto March 31, 1946, and closes the door to reopening accounts beyond that date.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that upon a fair reading of the compromise arrived at between the parties in the circumstances then existing, the only legitimate conclusion possible is that the parties had agreed to confine the taking of all accounts upto March 31,1946, and had closed the door to reopening them beyond that date.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fair reading of compromise text in light of surrounding circumstances, including plaintiff's notice to exclusively run liquor shops post-31.3.46 and position of vantage; trial court finding of no vitiation upheld.

holdings.text: The compromise closed once for all the controversy about taking any account of the joint family businesses including the motor business after the 31st March, 1946, and the plaintiff is bound by the terms of the compromise and the consent decree following upon it.

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that the compromise closed once for all the controversy about taking any account of the joint family businesses including the motor business after the 31st March, 1946, and the plaintiff is bound by the terms of the compromise and the consent decree following upon it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Parties dealt at arms length; compromise arrived after full consideration; plaintiff abandoned later application alleging misapprehension.

holdings.text: The plaintiff is barred by the principle of res judicata from reagitating the question in the present suit.

anchor.surface_text: The obvious effect of this finding is that the plaintiff is barred by the principle of res judicata from reagitating the question in the present suit. It is well settled that a consent decree is as binding upon the parties thereto as a decree passed by invitum.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consent decree as binding as decree passed on contest; compromise not vitiated by fraud, misrepresentation, mistake or misunderstanding.

holdings.text: The plaintiff's claim is barred by the provisions of Order II, rule 2(3), of the Code of Civil Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: We are also of opinion that the plaintiffs claim is barred by the provisions of Order II, rule 2 3 , of the Code of Civil Procedure. The plaintiff by confining his claim to account up to March 31, 1946, only, implicitly or explicitly, relinquished his claim to the account for the subsequent period.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff omitted to sue for all reliefs entitled in prior suit by confining accounts to 31.3.46, relinquishing subsequent claim without court leave.

holdings.text: The cause of action in the two suits is the same.

anchor.surface_text: We do not agree with the High Court that the cause of action in the subsequent suit was different from the cause of action in the first suit. The cause of action in the first suit was the desire of the plaintiff to separate from his brothers and to divide the joint family property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both suits based on desire to separate and divide joint family property; prior suit embraced entire property without reservation except as per compromise.

holdings.text: No further question as to the applicability of section 90 of the Indian Trusts Act can possibly arise.

anchor.surface_text: As the suit is barred both by res judicata and Order II, rule 2 3 , of the Civil Procedure Code, no further question as to the applicability of section 90 of the Indian Trusts Act can possibly arise under the circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit fails on threshold bars of res judicata and O.II r.2(3); no occasion to consider Trusts Act liability.

holdings.text: The status of the parties after the compromise changed into one of tenants in common.

anchor.surface_text: the status of the parties thereafter changed into one of tenants in common.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compromise limited accounts to 31.3.46; plaintiff abandoned right to accounts thereafter.
